channel.title: Science : NPR
channel.description: The latest health and science news. Updates on medicine, healthy living, nutrition, drugs, diet, and advances in science and technology. Subscribe to the Health & Science podcast.

item.title: Untangling The Mystery Of Why Shoelaces Come Untied
item.description: April 17, 2017 - Scientists at the University of California, Berkeley have figured out why shoelaces seem to come untied at the worst moments, like when you're running.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 17, 2017 - Scientists at the University of California, Berkeley have figured out why shoelaces seem to come untied at the worst moments, like when you're running. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/04/17/523636317/untangling-the-mystery-of-why-shoelaces-come-untied

item.title: Climate Change In Louisiana Changes Diets Of Native Americans
item.description: April 16, 2017 - Freelance journalist Barry Yeoman says climate change and other man-made obstacles are pushing Native Americans away from traditional foods and towards processed dinners.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 16, 2017 - Freelance journalist Barry Yeoman says climate change and other man-made obstacles are pushing Native Americans away from traditional foods and towards processed dinners. http://www.npr.org/2017/04/16/524242254/climate-change-in-louisiana-changes-diets-of-native-americans

item.title: Spider Scientists Find 50 New Species
item.description: April 16, 2017 - A team of arachnologists discovered over 50 new species of spider in Cape York, Australia. Dr. Robert Raven is one of them. He tells Lulu Garcia-Navarro about the expedition and their findings.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 16, 2017 - A team of arachnologists discovered over 50 new species of spider in Cape York, Australia. Dr. Robert Raven is one of them. He tells Lulu Garcia-Navarro about the expedition and their findings. http://www.npr.org/2017/04/16/524177420/spider-scientists-find-50-new-species

item.title: As A Boy, He Learned About Science By Rubbing Calves' Ears
item.description: April 16, 2017 - Dr. Thumbi Mwangi had a eureka moment when he began researching a cattle disease in the U.S. The treatment was the same thing his dad the farmer had him do when he was growing up in Kenya.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 16, 2017 - Dr. Thumbi Mwangi had a eureka moment when he began researching a cattle disease in the U.S. The treatment was the same thing his dad the farmer had him do when he was growing up in Kenya. http://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2017/04/16/508235759/as-a-boy-he-learned-about-science-by-rubbing-calves-ears

item.title: Artist Sets Futuristic Dinner Party In World Reshaped By Rising Seas
item.description: April 16, 2017 - How will our diets shift as climate change causes sea-level rise and coastal flooding? Photographer Allie Wist attempts to answer that with pictures of an imagined "post-sea-level-rise dinner party."
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 16, 2017 - How will our diets shift as climate change causes sea-level rise and coastal flooding? Photographer Allie Wist attempts to answer that with pictures of an imagined "post-sea-level-rise dinner party." http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2017/04/16/520294246/artist-sets-futuristic-dinner-party-in-world-reshaped-by-rising-seas

item.title: The Poetic Intimacy Of Administering Anesthesia
item.description: April 16, 2017 - An anesthesiologist and poet says her medical work is well-suited to poetry, as patients move in and out of consciousness under the doctor's watch.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 16, 2017 - An anesthesiologist and poet says her medical work is well-suited to poetry, as patients move in and out of consciousness under the doctor's watch. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/04/16/523816317/the-poetic-intimacy-of-administering-anesthesia

item.title: U.S. Health Care Wrestles With The 'Pre-Existing Condition'
item.description: April 15, 2017 - Insurers and politicians struggle constantly to thread the needle between making sure people have good health insurance and figuring out who should pay, especially for those who need a lot of care.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 15, 2017 - Insurers and politicians struggle constantly to thread the needle between making sure people have good health insurance and figuring out who should pay, especially for those who need a lot of care. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/04/15/523577871/u-s-health-care-wrestles-with-the-pre-existing-condition

item.title: Researchers Find A New Way To Make Water From Thin Air
item.description: April 14, 2017 - The device isn't the first technology that can turn water vapor into drinkable liquid water. But its creators say it uses less power and works in drier conditions — the key is something called a MOF.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 14, 2017 - The device isn't the first technology that can turn water vapor into drinkable liquid water. But its creators say it uses less power and works in drier conditions — the key is something called a MOF. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/04/14/523796745/researchers-find-a-new-way-to-make-water-from-thin-air

item.title: How A Budget Squeeze Can Lead To Sloppy Science And Even Cheating
item.description: April 14, 2017 - The hypercompetitive world of biomedical research occasionally drives scientists to cheat. More often, scientists make decisions that undercut their results. That can lead colleagues astray.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 14, 2017 - The hypercompetitive world of biomedical research occasionally drives scientists to cheat. More often, scientists make decisions that undercut their results. That can lead colleagues astray. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/04/14/523786179/how-a-budget-squeeze-can-lead-to-sloppy-science-and-even-cheating

item.title: Scientists Find Signs That Saturn's Moon Enceladus Might Be Hospitable To Life
item.description: April 13, 2017 - "This is the closest we've come, so far, to identifying a place with some of the ingredients needed for a habitable environment," NASA says. There are signs of a promising reaction under the surface.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 13, 2017 - "This is the closest we've come, so far, to identifying a place with some of the ingredients needed for a habitable environment," NASA says. There are signs of a promising reaction under the surface. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/04/13/523756092/signs-of-hospitality-to-life-found-on-saturns-moon-enceladus

item.title: A New Approach To Helping Men Of Color Heal After A Violent Incident
item.description: April 13, 2017 - To figure out the best ways to help young black and Latino men heal, a nonprofit will train young men in New York City to conduct interviews with other young men of color.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 13, 2017 - To figure out the best ways to help young black and Latino men heal, a nonprofit will train young men in New York City to conduct interviews with other young men of color. http://www.npr.org/sections/codeswitch/2017/04/13/523746277/a-new-approach-to-helping-men-of-color-heal-after-a-violent-incident

item.title: Eels May Use 'Magnetic Maps' As They Slither Across The Ocean
item.description: April 13, 2017 - Eels sometimes swim thousands of miles from their birthplace in the Atlantic to rivers and lakes where they live. Researchers say the creatures might use the Earth's magnetic field to find their way.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 13, 2017 - Eels sometimes swim thousands of miles from their birthplace in the Atlantic to rivers and lakes where they live. Researchers say the creatures might use the Earth's magnetic field to find their way. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/04/13/523450769/eels-may-use-magnetic-maps-as-they-slither-across-the-ocean

item.title: How Can The Colorado River Continue To Support 36 Million People In 7 States?
item.description: April 13, 2017 - New Yorker staff writer David Owen says that convoluted legal agreements and a patchwork of infrastructure determine how water from the Colorado is allocated. His new book is Where The Water Goes.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 13, 2017 - New Yorker staff writer David Owen says that convoluted legal agreements and a patchwork of infrastructure determine how water from the Colorado is allocated. His new book is Where The Water Goes. http://www.npr.org/2017/04/13/523717152/how-can-the-colorado-river-continue-to-support-36-million-people-in-7-states

item.title: What Doesn't Kill You Can Maim: Unexpected Injuries From Opioids
item.description: April 13, 2017 - Emergency room doctors are just beginning to study a new kind of casualty in the opioid epidemic — patients who survive an overdose, but walk away with brain damage, kidney failure or dead muscle.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 13, 2017 - Emergency room doctors are just beginning to study a new kind of casualty in the opioid epidemic — patients who survive an overdose, but walk away with brain damage, kidney failure or dead muscle. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/04/13/523452905/what-doesnt-kill-you-can-maim-unexpected-injuries-from-opioids

item.title: There Are More Than 60,000 Tree Species Worldwide, Scientists Say
item.description: April 12, 2017 - More than half of those species are only found in a single country, and many of them face extinction. The scientists hope that this database will be an important tool for conservationists.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: April 12, 2017 - More than half of those species are only found in a single country, and many of them face extinction. The scientists hope that this database will be an important tool for conservationists. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/04/12/523616033/there-are-60-000-species-of-tree-worldwide-scientists-say
